titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. This Evening I spent an hour at my father’s, where were Mr and Mrs: Quincy—Mr: and Mrs: Cranch, and Mrs: Clarke a Lady who lives with them— I pass’d more time than usual in my Garden, but translated two or three chapters of Aristotle, for my lecture— Read Odyssey Book 11.

2. I was unable to procure either of the two Chairs which I have been accustomed to use, and the Stage did not as usual go to Boston this morning— I therefore determined to walk into Boston, and left my house at about 8 this morning for that purpose. When I reached Mr: Apthorp’s I met T. Welsh, and his Sister Harriet, who were coming to my House— He left her there and immediately returned— He overtook me, about two miles from home, and brought me in to Boston— I immediately walk’d to Cambridge, and attended Dr: Warren’s lecture, Introductory to the medical courses; from 11. to 12. O’Clock— I dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and at 2. P.M. attended the Declamations which were better than usual, though longer— I intended to have returned to Boston in the Stage, but before the Declamations were finished it was gone— I therefore walked back into Boston— Called at Mr: Shaw’s Office, where I spent an hour— Evening at Whitcomb’s where I lodged— The House is full of lodgers.

div.p: 3. Walk’d up to Cambridge again early this morning— Call’d at Dr: Waterhouse’s—and at 10 O’Clock, or rather a quarter of an hour after, read my seventh Lecture— After which I went with Mr: Ware, and looked over the house which he formerly occupied, I called on the President, who was attending a Government meeting at Mr: Farrar’s chamber— He informed me that the Corporation had yesterday agreed to change the day for Declamation, from Thursday to Friday— But this must yet be confirmed by the Overseers, who are to meet the 16th: of this month— Untill which I must continue to attend both days— I returned with Mr: Shaw to Boston— Saw Mr: Gardner, who resides in my house, and agreed to allow a ventilator to be made to prevent the house from smoking— Call’d on Mr: Walton respecting his house at Cambridge— Dined at Whitcomb’s— Came out in the Milton Stage, to Milton bridge— Walk’d from thence to my father’s; and thence home in his Chaise— On reaching home I found that my house had been broken open and robb’d last Night—principally of articles of provision.

4. My father was here this morning— The two Mrs: Blake’s called in the afternoon— Caroline and Harriet Welsh went to Mr: T. Greenleaf’s— I was at my father’s in the Evening— Wrote scarcely half a page the whole day—

5. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— Caroline and Harriet Welsh went to my fathers in the afternoon— I was there half an hour in the Evening— Called also at Mr Cranch’s.— Did nothing this day; and have nothing to say—

6. My father and his family, and Mr: and Mrs: Cranch dined with us this day— In the evening there was company here at tea— Mr: Apthorp & his family, & Mr: & Mrs: Black &c— Harriet Welsh left us, and went home with Louisa Smith— I wrote a little this morning—but in the afternoon and Evening was engaged entirely with Company. Mrs: Tufts and her niece called here this afternoon, but would not stay.

7. Mrs: Adams very unwell, with a sore throat, and fever— This afternoon I attended a meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge, at the House belonging to the Company— Met Mr: Boylston there— He has very lately returned from a tour to Nova-Scotia—we transacted the business and adjourned to the next quarterly meeting in January— Evening, read Odyssey Book 12.

8. Training day for the militia at Braintree— This afternoon, Mrs: Adams and Caroline went with Harriet Welsh, and my niece Susan, escorted by Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: to Germantown— Mr: Quincy called on me— Spent an hour this Evening at my fathers— Lectures much neglected— I am still abstracting from Aristotle on the Passions.

9. Called on Mr: Quincy at 8 this morning, and took him with me in to Boston— I was variously busied there, untill noon— Went to Cambridge in the Stage— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Attended the Declamation—the Speaking continues to improve; but the company was this day somewhat disorderly.— Immediately after the declamations, I walk’d back into Boston— Employed part of the Evening, writing to Mrs: Susan Hall of Barbadoes— Walk in the Mall, with Mr: J. Gardner—

10. Walk’d up to Cambridge early this morning, and read my 8th: Lecture—at 10. O’Clock— Afterwards called on President Webber, and delivered to him the Monitor’s Bills which had been given to me yesterday— I had some conversation with him respecting the propriety of fines for absence from these exercises, upon which he proposed to consult the corporation— I returned into Boston with Mr: Shaw—and was occupied all the rest of the morning—chiefly in arrangements to send away the books for the Library of Congress— I dined with Mr: Gardner— Called at the Secretary of the State’s Office, for a set of the Statutes of the Commonwealth for the Library; which however I could not obtain— I returned in the Evening to Quincy; found my youngest child had been very ill in my absence; though now recovering.

11. My brother with his wife and child returned last Evening from Haverhill and Newbury-Port— He was here this afternoon— My father called in the morning—I walk’d down to his House in the Evening— I wrote this day very little.— Read in the Evening Odyssey. Book 13.

12. Heard Mr: Harris of Dorchester— His morning text was from Proverbs XXIII.26. “My son give me thine heart”— The Sermon was very good— His Introduction was an Hypothesis—“If God should confer personally with us and intreat us to do what is most beneficial to our own happiness—should not we be grateful—all duty—all obedience—all love?— Well! He has thus conferr’d with us; not personally; but in the Scriptures[”]— The division was into two points— 1. What is meant by giving the heart to God?—and 2. Inducements to comply with the request— Giving the heart, is that obedience which a grateful child, would pay to an indulgent parent— The inducements are 1. Bounden duty and 2. Highest Interest—this last subdivision led naturally to the conclusion which made an animated appeal to the feelings—particularly the selfish feelings— The style was perspicuous and plain—the delivery far above the common level—without cant—and with due attention to the accent, emphasis and pause— But under the disadvantage of an unmelodious voice, and with some affectation of manner— There is a consciousness of genius, overrated or at least too apparent, and an anxiety to strike, which is manifest in every look and gesture of Harris— He seems in every sentence to call upon his hearer for admiration— To say, is not this ingenious—well arranged—well spoken? and sometimes—is not this wonderful?— His afternoon Sermon appears to have been written solely for that purpose— His text was Genesis XXV.14. “And Mishma, and Dumah, and Massa.”— They were three of the children of Ishmael, which led him to an historical account of that personage, and of his descendants the Arabians—this formed the introduction— But the names are significant—Obedience—Resignation—and Reliance— The sermon therefore was a dissertation upon Christian names. Very short; and purposely shortened in the delivery— But its merit was by no means equal to its singularity— I spent part of the Evening, at my fathers— And afterwards read the Odyssey Book 14.
13. This afternoon Mrs: Adams rode out with the children and Caroline, and afterwards I rode with her round the Braintree Square— In the Evening I read the Odyssey, Books 15 and 16.

14. Mrs: Adams went out with Caroline and the children this afternoon to ride—when they had been gone about two hours Caroline came back with George; Mr: Tufts’s boy came with them; and they had left Mrs: Adams with John, at Mr: Tufts’s— Near his house, the horse had taken a fright and overset the Chaise— In the fall, both Mrs: Adams and John had got slight bruises— They were afraid to return alone— I immediately went with the Chaise to Mr: Tufts’s, and
brought home Mrs: Adams and John— I bless heaven, that in this dangerous accident they all escaped with very little hurt— Miss Edes and Harriet Welsh called here soon after they went out— Mr: T. Greenleaf was also here— His son, and Harriet Welsh spent the Evening with us— I wrote of my lectures a little more than usual.
15. All the family pass’d the afternoon, and I remained part of the Evening, at my father’s— I continued writing on the first draught of my lectures— After I came home, I read the Odyssey Book 17.

16. I went into Boston this morning with Mrs: Adams and George in the Stage— They returned home at Night; but I remained in Boston— I went up to Cambridge to dinner. Attended the Declamation at 2. and immediately afterwards I spent the Evening alone at Whitcomb’s—reading in Aikin’s annual Review

div.p: 17. I walked up again to Cambridge this morning, immediately after Breakfast— I heard part of a medical lecture from Dr: Waterhouse— At 10. I read my 9th: Lecture, on the Topics— It is the least valuable, and pleased the least of any that I have yet given— After finishing, I attended a Lecture of Dr: Warren, upon Anatomy— He was dissecting a body, and it required some strength of nerve to attend duly to the lesson— But I regret that I have not the opportunity to attend a whole course. After the lecture I called upon the President, to enquire whether the Overseers had met, and agreed to the arrangement which would require my attendance only one day in the week— They did not meet yesterday as he had expected; and accordingly I must continue to go twice, the remainder of the time that I can attend this Season— I also requested him to take the necessary measures respecting the Declamations, in my absence; as I can attend only two weeks more— I then return’d to Boston and dined at Whitcomb’s— After dinner, I made some further unsuccessful inquiries for a house, or boarding place to accommodate Mrs: Adams, and the children in the Winter— Came out in the Milton Stage; and from the Bridge, walk’d home— Stopping about half an hour at my father’s.

18. This afternoon I took George with me, over part of the farm; with the view to familiarize him at this season of his life, with the scenes upon which my own earliest recollection dwells.— I feel an attachment to these places more powerful than to any other spot upon Earth— Precisely because they are associated with the first impressions of which the traces remain upon my mind— These attachments are connected with some of the sentiments and opinions which I most cherish, and which I should wish my children to possess— In the Evening I read Odyssey. Book 18.

19. Heard Mr: Whitney all day— Afternoon at my father’s— He was somewhat unwell— There came Company in the Evening: Mr: & Mrs: Cranch—Mr: & Mrs: Beale—Mr: & Mrs: Greenleaf— I came home early, and brought George with me— Read the Odyssey Book 19.

20. I went with Caroline to Captain Beale’s this afternoon and Evening— Mrs: Adams did not go— But spent the afternoon at my father’s, with my brother’s wife, whose child is very dangerously ill— He went to Boston this morning, and returned at Night— I finished the first draught of my lecture, with which I close the subject of Invention— I commence next upon Disposition— But did not this day begin.

21. Took a ride this afternoon, with my wife, and youngest child, who is yet quite unwell— Mrs: Adams went to my father’s afterwards, but returned home to tea— I went there myself in the Evening— My brother came from Boston, and brought Mrs: Harrod with him— I wrote but little and read not much.

22. My father was at my house this forenoon— In the afternoon Mrs: Adams and Caroline went to my father’s, where my brother’s child still continues extremely ill— I was also there in the Evening— After my return I read the Odyssey Book 20.

23. Went into Boston this morning in the Stage, with Caroline; who is going to pass a week at Dr: Welsh’s.— I was employed, about in Boston untill 1. P.M— when I took a light dinner at Whitcomb’s, and walk’d to Cambridge— Found at Dr: Waterhouse’s Miss Gleason, and Miss Gourgas— At 2. I attended the Declamations which were indifferent— Returned immediately afterwards in the Stage to Boston— Found R. Amory— Mr: Lisle, and Churchill, at Whitcomb’s— My brother also came in soon after— In the Evening, I called on Mr: H. Gardner—and also at Dr: Welsh’s; but the family were not at home— There was a dancing-school Ball, at Concert Hall—very noisy, and very late— Just as I was going to bed Mrs: Whitcomb came in, & told us Mrs: Smith had sent in word that she had just lost her youngest child John—with the Croup— He has been unwell, several days; but never thought dangerously so untill this day, about noon.

div.p: 24. Immediately on rising this morning, I called to see Mr: Smith and his family— Found them in deep affliction— Mrs: Smith especially, the mother; was distress’d in the extreme— It is the second young child who has lost within a few months, and the tenderness of the mother suffers in every fibre— I went up to Cambridge with her son William, who went out immediately to return— I attended a lecture of Dr: Waterhouse— It was on the subject of Sympathy—the same on which he published his inaugural Dissertation at Leyden— At 10. O’Clock I delivered my lecture 10. on Demonstrative Eloquence.— It was rather longer than usual— I called at Dr: Warren’s, but his lecture was to commence so late that I could not stay for it. Walk’d into Boston— Was much engaged untill dinner time— Called twice on Mr: Bussey— Dined with Mr: D. Sears—in company with Mr: Boylston, and Mr: John Parker— After dinner called on S. Higginson junr, whom I could not find before, went with him to Mrs: Barrell’s to look at her chamber’s, which Mrs: Adams had thoughts of engaging for the Winter.— But I think them not sufficient— I promised Mr: Higginson a final answer to-morrow— I came out to Quincy, in a Chaise of Mr: Boylston, who sent a boy with me; and to take back the chair— I stop’d at my father’s; and walk’d home from his house— Found Mr: T. Greenleaf junr, and Miss Edes, at my house— Miss Edes to spend some days—

25. I breakfasted this morning at my father’s, and took a letter for Mr: Higginson, which my brother carried with him to Boston. Looked up some old papers at the request of Mr: Boylston— In the afternoon I took a walk over the brook, with Miss Edes towards the rocky hills at the back of my house— Evening at home— John our youngest child was somewhat unwell—

26. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day; but without that attention which is due to the services of the day— I could not help it— Miss Edes went to meeting with me; but did not return— In the Evening I went to my father’s— As I was returning I met Charles the servant Boy, who told me Mrs: Adams had fainted away— On reaching home I found Dr: Phipps, and Mrs: Briesler, with her— She soon recovered considerably—

27. Mrs: Adams had intended to go this morning to Boston, but concluded finally to stay— She is this day quite recovered— I was employed all day in writing; though not upon my lectures— In the Evening I spent an hour at my fathers.

28. This afternoon I rode with Mrs: Adams, and John as far as Randolph— We returned to tea at Mr: Cranch’s— Mr: and Mrs: D. Greenleaf were there— We came home early in the Evening; and I read a Chapter from the Tale of the Tub.

29. My brother sent us this morning a pair of Brants, and came and dined with us; in the afternoon I went with him to my father’s— I took from my Trunk the letter Book, to which Mr: Boylston wishes a reference, to take with me to Boston— After returning home, I read the Odyssey, Book 21.

30. Mrs: Adams went with me to Boston, and we took John with us— We travell’d the whole way, under a steady Snow, blowing in upon us— Mrs: Adams stop’d at Concert Hall— I went to Cambridge in the Stage— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s. attended the Declamation at 2 O’Clock; and returned again in the Stage to Boston— I called at Mr: Storer’s; at whose house I found company; and at Dr: Welsh’s, where Mrs: Adams took tea— Her Sister Caroline is there— We lodged at Whitcomb’s—and met Mr: & Mrs: Bernard there at supper—

div.p: 31. I went up to Cambridge this morning, as early as I could get from Boston— Heard part of a Lecture from Dr: Waterhouse on Fevers— At 10. I delivered my 11th: Lecture— Called and took leave of the President; who informed me that the Overseers had agreed to the holding of the Declamations on Friday’s, for the future— So that my attendance will be necessary only one day, in the week— I returned immediately after seeing the President to Boston— Called again on Mr: Storer— Mr: T. Perkins for the Overseers of John Boylston’s donation requested my opinion in writing, respecting their title to the Estate conveyed to them by M. Gill— I spent a great part of the day in endeavouring to procure lodgings & board for my family during the Winter; but without success— We dined at Whitcomb’s, and returned with a very dark Evening to Quincy— We were happy enough to meet no accident.
Day— As the last month— Excepting that I have been obliged to pass two days in a week at Boston & Cambridge.
